author: sendmoodz
content: i just came to ask about some edits i want to make to the eip. in particular i want the transient storage to behave exactly the same as regular storage with regards to reverts. the data structure that would be used to do this i expect is a stack of maps which has o(1) tstore time and o(m) where m is number of call frames tload time and o(1) time in case of reverts and o(n) time in case of success where n is number of transient keys set. this makes it seem like a fixed gas cost of 8 could create potential for a ddos by growing the call stack a lot and doing a bunch of sloads, or creating a deep stack and then setting a bunch of transient keys

author: sendmoodz
content: can anyone comment on a better data structure to handle reverts for transient storage? how are sloads and sstores kept in memory to handle reverts?

author: sendmoodz
content: the other problem with this solution (besides still requiring a cold sload) is the refunds were limited to 20% in london, so if you use a bunch of slots in a transient way, which is my use case, you have to also spend a lot of gas in the tx to get the full refund
